text: Which kind of metrics do you use for tracking how well is doing really your model against the market? I mean, a metric which is able to determine if the model is having some negative variance or if it is really performing bad. I know about looking at the profit at BSP, I wonder if there are other methodologies. Thank you :pray:

elements.text: Which kind of metrics do you use for tracking how well is doing really your model against the market? I mean, a metric which is able to determine if the model is having some negative variance or if it is really performing bad. I know about looking at the profit at BSP, I wonder if there are other methodologies. Thank you

text:
It’s more about expected value assuming BSP is true rather than profit at BSP

For me, this is the approach but the problem is what to use as fair value in contexts where BSP is not available. For example, in play

elements.text: It’s

more about expected value assuming BSP is true rather than profit at BSP

For me, this is the approach but the problem is what to use as fair value in contexts where BSP is not available
For example, in play

text: Do you have some clues in those cases if you want to share?

elements.text: Do you have some clues in those cases if you want to share?

text: Depends on the sport. In something highly structured like tennis you can use where the market settles to after each point. For unstructured, the best I have at the moment is use the market price X seconds after the bet

elements.text: Depends on the sport. In something highly structured like tennis you can use where the market settles to after each point. For unstructured, the best I have at the moment is use the market price X seconds after the bet

text: Also depends on why you think you’re finding value in these situations. If you think the market is completely bonkers for long periods of the event then it’s not helpful to use the market to calculate EV. On the other hand if you think you’re profiting off short term mispricing then it makes perfect sense to evaluate the bets once the market has adjusted

elements.text: Also depends on why you think you’re finding value in these situations. If you think the market is completely bonkers for long periods of the event then it’s not helpful to use the market to calculate EV. On the other hand if you think you’re profiting off short term mispricing then it makes perfect sense to evaluate the bets once the market has adjusted

text: In low liquid markets you also need to try and separate market impact from your metric

elements.text: In low liquid markets you also need to try and separate market impact from your metric

text:
*Trading System*

Hi guys,
I wrote my own trading system using betfairlightweight to keep the stream connection. One of the issues I face sometimes is that I get the marketbook stream update before the order stream update. For instance, when I manually cancel an order thorugh the UI, I might not replace it because the marketbook update came before the order update. Have you guys had this issue? How did you deal with it (Other than tweaking the conflate) ?

elements.text: Trading System

How did you deal with it (Other than tweaking the conflate) ?

text:
Guys,
what's wrong on this function?
```def place_order(size, price, selection_id, trading, market_id, lay="LAY"):
    # placing an order
    limit_order = filters.limit_order(size=size, price=price, persistence_type="LAPSE")
    instruction = filters.place_instruction(
        order_type="LIMIT",
        selection_id=selection_id,
        side=lay,
        limit_order=limit_order,
    )
    place_orders = trading.betting.place_orders(
        market_id=market_id, instructions=[instruction]  # list
    )
    return place_order```
```U.place_order(1, 1.1, 1.217703269, trading, 4940266, lay="BACK")```
```APIError: SportsAPING/v1.0/placeOrders 
Params: {'marketId': '4940266', 'instructions': [{'orderType': 'LIMIT', 'selectionId': '1.217703269', 'side': 'BACK', 'limitOrder': {'price': 1.1, 'persistenceType': 'LAPSE', 'size': 1}}]} 
Exception: None 
Error: {'code': -32602, 'message': 'DSC-0018'} 
Full Response: {'jsonrpc': '2.0', 'error': {'code': -32602, 'message': 'DSC-0018'}, 'id': 1}```

elements.text:
Guys,
what's wrong on this function?

def place_order(size, price, selection_id, trading, market_id, lay="LAY"):
    # placing an order
    limit_order = filters.limit_order(size=size, price=price, persistence_type="LAPSE")
    instruction = filters.place_instruction(
        order_type="LIMIT",
        selection_id=selection_id,
        side=lay,
        limit_order=limit_order,
    )
    place_orders = trading.betting.place_orders(
        market_id=market_id, instructions=[instruction]  # list
    )
    return place_order
U.place_order(1, 1.1, 1.217703269, trading, 4940266, lay="BACK")

text:
Hi all, hope you had a fruitful bank holiday... potential noob question again so apologies if it's documented somewhere (in which case please could you point me in the direction of the page).

Using marketrecorder.py and flumine, mainly based on the examples, I have recorded something like 30,000 markets.   It looks like the market catalogue files (.json.gz) are saved for only about 10,000 of them, so there are a load of market stream text files which don't have the metadata stored.  Is there a way to get the market catalogue data retrospectively?  And does it sound like I am using the recorder incorrectly for this to happen in the first place?

text: Not always. The greyhound BSP markets can be quite thin, leading to some strange results. If you’re trying to assess the ev point, you’d be better using the prices close to the scheduled start time.

text: <@U4H19D1D2> I keep a local cache with my open orders. If for some reason, I manually cancel an order though the UI and I receive the orderbook update thorugh the stream before I receive the order update, my internal cache will think I still have that order open and do nothing. I only react to book updates (not order updates), so when I finally receive the order update, I will update the order cache, but I will only replace the order when I receive a next orderbook update thorugh the stream (which in small markets might take quite a while). This is not a problem only in case of manual cancels thorugh the UI, but also if there is an order fill.

elements.text: I keep a local cache with my open orders. If for some reason, I manually cancel an order though the UI and I receive the orderbook update thorugh the stream before I receive the order update, my internal cache will think I still have that order open and do nothing. I only react to book updates (not order updates), so when I finally receive the order update, I will update the order cache, but I will only replace the order when I receive a next orderbook update thorugh the stream (which in small markets might take quite a while). This is not a problem only in case of manual cancels thorugh the UI, but also if there is an order fill.

So in flumine we use a timeout on the queue to push a snap of the stream cache, you can see the logic here or just migrate to flumine and never think about this again…

<https://github.com/betcode-org/flumine/blob/796ec51060328edac7e14678c6defd63a964d250/flumine/streams/marketstream.py#L59|https://github.com/betcode-org/flumine/blob/796ec51060328edac7e14678c6defd63a964d250/flumine/streams/marketstream.py#L59>

text: In case of order fills that could happen as well. What I find weird is that I am conflating the marketstream to 100ms, and 0ms for orders, so it should pretty much never happen. I have profiled my code, and the operations I do before updating my orders cache when I get an update from the order stream takes around 15 nanoseconds, so I should acknowledge the orders way before I guess. For less liquid markets, conflated and not-conflated might be the same though...

text:
Hey guys.
Let's suppose I run 2 different strategies for the same markets within the same instance of Flumine, Strategy A and B, both in paper trade mode. Let's suppose I placed an order using Strategy A. If I later place a new order using Strategy B, does Flumine take into account the bet previously placed with Strategy A in the market to handle new bet?

elements.text:
Hey guys.
Let's suppose I run 2 different strategies for the same markets within the same instance of Flumine, Strategy A and B, both in paper trade mode. Let's suppose I placed an order using Strategy A. If I later place a new order using Strategy B, does Flumine take into account the bet previously placed with Strategy A in the market to handle new bet?

text:
If you are taking prices we don’t handle double counting of liquidity.

Passive bets can be either isolated (default) or combined using a config setting

don’t

Passive bets can be either isolated (default) or combined using a config setting
